page.title: 02FARMING IN THE AREA
page.content: There is much farmland south of Maidstone. Barley seems to be the major corn crop, but there are also many orchards, most of which have had their big old trees uprooted and been replanted with the closer-spaced and more dwarf species. Many of the sheep are varieties of the Romney Marsh breed, but Home Farm has Border Leicester x Grey Face, bred, we were told, for both their meat and their wool; the lambs not required are sold at 3 months old. Coppicing takes place in a number of Sweet Chestnut plantations in the area. The trees are allowed to grow for 15 years or so and are then cut down and made into spile-fencing and hop-poles etc. They then grow again on their remaining stumps for another 15 years.
